intro: Potamogeton × zizii f. coriaceus, commonly known as the thick-leaved pondweed, is a hybrid aquatic plant that exhibits characteristics of both its parent species, Potamogeton zizii and Potamogeton × zizii. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in freshwater environments, such as ponds and slow-moving streams. The plant is distinguished by its thick, leathery leaves that are often arranged in whorls around the stem. Its flowers are small and greenish, typically appearing in clusters, and it produces small, three-lobed fruits. This plant plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
